comments.body: The registration of `RequantizePerChannel` and `RequantizationRangePerChannel` ops must be inside the `#ifdef INTEL_MKL` guard, because their kernel builders are only defined with config=mkl.

The Op needs to be available outside of MKL also, as there is no TF(Eigen) Op available with the same name. This is required for pbtxt , else API tests will fail. let me know if this is not clear. Tomorrow in the meeting with Intel and Google AG Ramesh might add more or else I can explain in detail.

these 2 tests will pass only the way I have it now for both Eigen and MKL
1.//tensorflow/core/kernels:mkl_requantize_ops_test
2.tensorflow/core/api_def/api_test

Thank you for the explanation! I was under the impression that registering the op without having a kernel builder (in the non-MKL case) would have a problem. I agree that it works fine. Saw that a lot of other MKL code does it this way too. :)
Can you add a unit test for the shape function here: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/ops/math_ops_test.cc
Could you please the @compatibility decorator here, as requested?
done!
Thanks!
@lakshayg Hmm I don't see it. Did you forget to merge it?
Here: [a7c7907](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/10643/commits/a7c7907b9d0b539ec5cf9bdc3c98a387b84f8935)
Thanks.
numpy uses x1, x2. It's ugly but we probably want to stay consistent.
This probably needs more documentation and examples, given how confusing rounding is :)

Interesting the underyling `std::rint` operator behaves differently based on the current rounding mode: [std::fesetround](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/numeric/fenv/FE_round). Seems TF does not set this explicitly in the code base neither does Eigen (checked this doing an ack fsetround). Should we set the mode explicitly ?

@girving would have useful knowledge here.

I guess you meant @girving  ?
I'm on the fence about whether setting the flags is worth the trouble.  If someone sets the processor flags I'm okay making them suffer the consequences.

If we do adjust the flags, it should happen right here:

https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/lib/core/threadpool.cc#L52

There is no need to save and reset the flags, since it will be thread local.  You'll need to do something similar to ScopedFlushDenormal.

Returns element-wise integer closest to x.

comments.body:
Despite numpy convention, typically when I do a scan I want the exclusive version with `output[0] = identity`.  In particular, that's the kind of scan necessary to do safe gradients of `reduce_prod`.

How difficult would a possibly optional exclusive scan be to arrange?

I've though about this when writing the op.
I'm not sure how to neatly make the exclusive version accessible in Eigen, except by creating a new `cumsum_exclusive(...)` method.
Maybe it's enough to only add this on the TensorFlow side by optionally padding the tensor with the value that we get from `Reducer::initialize()` ?
Let's get this one in and worry about the exclusive version later if necessary.

We won't be able to compile this PR right now, as Eigen hasn't been updated to the latest version yet :(
I'll have a look at implementing the `exclusive=True/False` kwarg
